name: Silhouette/Blackmail
Psi Tax
description:
Drain with ICE, and score with Caprice whenever you can.

Shocks stop Datasuckers, Snares stop R&D digs.

Closed Accounts is better than Scorched Earth as tag punishment from Cerebral Casts, and plays to the Psi game of Nisei Division. If they do take the brain damage, they'll be a lot easier to kill with Snares and Philotic Entanglement later on.

name: PadBar Warszawa 29.04.2014
description: The deck I actually played in that tournament :)

name: House of Cards v1.1
description:
This deck requires a certain amount of ballsiness to play. All of the ICE crumbles to Parasite. Your income comes only from drip Assets and clicking. There's not a reliable way to flatline the Runner.

Ideally the Runner will find the lone Project Junebug in HQ or R&D and wonder if the card you installed with Mushin no Shin is a second. Hopefully it's a GRNDL Refinery.

I'll probably never be completely satisfied with the ICE, but this is getting closer. I'd still like to get something else that can deal tags, though the one from Snare! is still the best source for Jinteki as it doesn't immediately signal the deck has any tag punishment.

name: Life and Death v2
description:
My Jinteki netdamage deck. This theme might be a hard one to pull off, but I love the idea of a Jinteki hospital that looks great on the outside, but once you step in, it's nothing but death for the intruder.

Played 5 games with it till now. Won 4. 3 of which were flatlines.

The main issue up till now is ICE and economy balance. This deck only has 12 pieces of ice, which is the absolute minimal, even with a 44 card deck. Also this deck has a lot of agenda's, something I also have to tweak with. I've added Shiro as a agenda protector. Tollbooth, archer and Tsurugi are my remote agenda protectors. Private contracts I often leave unprotected. I'm thinking about switching it up for operation economy.

This deck will undergo a lot of changes coming weeks and any feedback will be great. Till now it has been great fun, but 1 or 2 errors and it's game over.

name: Central Express Tenma
description:
Who needs to spend a single click to check remotes, run into new Jinteki ambushes or waste a single credit to trash installed assets?

Or more importantly - who wants to wait for the corporation to install?

RUN QUICK and hit the centrals hard!

Main Strategy

  • Quick and decisive run-to-win strategy
  • Constantly running on centrals only with Siphon, Indexing (good against ambush-decks), Maker's Eye or Legwork, scoring those agendas.
  • Central-only ICE-breakers
  • Prepaid VoicePAD and Public Terminal to pay for events and runs

Cards to mulligan for

  • Siphon, Legwork, Prepaid, Indexing, Maker's eye

First turn

  • If possible, try and run on both HQ and R&D with the respective run-events (corp can't always rez both)

Second and further turns

  • Keep credits on a need-level and run often!
  • Use Express Delivery to get the 3 central-breakers
  • SOT and Levy to re-use runs

name: D@mnit Woodhouse
description: How I would play Ian. Passive econ and aesops

name: Black and Redguard
description: My first deck submission. Heavily influenced by the Blackguard of the Red Queen deck. I made some changes bound to my personal preference, but I'm still quite unsure about the deck. I'm greatful for any advice. Thanks!

name: The Brush is Mightier than the Blade
description:
After tinkering with my kit deck for the past several months, going through Cyber-Cypher, Torch, and Yogasuarus builds, I think I've hit on something I'm very proud of that's proven to be very effective.

The basic idea is to utilize Paintbrush to set up an awesome Gordian Blade run through a server. This is not a new strategy. However, I've found this deck to be incredibly consistent in getting money, tutors, or tools when you need them.

My two MVPs in the deck have been Demolition Run and Personal Workshop. Demo Run helps save money when you run into those pesky Jacksons or SanSans, and helps A LOT against the Future Perfect and NAPD Contract. Send those suckers to archives and run there until you get them. Personal Workshop alleviates the high cost of my hardware, Omega, Femme, Opus, etc. and I can use my leftover Stimhack credits to push them out when I need to.

The lone Deus X is to help against the upcoming onslaught of Jinteki decks, but I might replace it with Feedback Filter or Net Shield to have a more permanent solution. Other than that, I can't think of any changes I want to make to the deck right now, though if Tori Hanzo starts dominating my meta I'm definitely going to replace that 3rd Stimhack with something.

name: Tennin Hide and Go Seek
D@mnit Woodhouse 2.0
Trick Of Light Advance
description: My first corp deck. Influenced by a trick of light + biotic labor combo. Fast advancing at it's finest. Please comment. I'm grateful for any advice.

name: Final Fronteirsman
D@mnit Woodhouse 2.1
A Beautiful Overmind v3
description: Final-ish version of this thing, works well and fun to play!

name: Make a run...on the double v1.1
description: Based on feedback, switched doppelgänger to desperado. Dropped lawyer up and 1x power nap to squeeze in some data suckers. Dropped 1x blackmail and express deliveries to streamline down to 45 cards.

name: The Last Generation
description:
The Last Generation is inspired by the Bait and Blast deck that FFG promo-d [0] but with a bit more focus on advancing (and defending) agendas than flatlining the runner.

Mushin No Shin is key to the tactic.

  • early game (not necessarily first turn), it's great to push out an advanceable asset. If the runner bites, you could flatline them (or just trash their grip) with a Junebug or cost them a couple credits to trash a GRNDL Refinery. If the runner doesn't bite, you either have credits for days or a useful target for Trick of Light.

  • mid game it's good to force tempo on the runner. If the runner's grip is small (because they just hit a Snare or Project Junebug, for example), you can use Mushin No Shin to push through an agenda quickly.

  • late game it's good to bait damaging runs or set up a Trick of Light. Make them hit a Snare or Psychic Field and follow up with Cerebral Cast and/or Scorched Earth. Or just sneak through the final agenda in a remote server with some ICE on it, using Mushin No Shin as a distraction or Trick of Light battery.

Speaking of ICE, this deck obviously doesn't have a lot of it. So you have to use it carefully.

  • Walls of Thorns are great for central servers.

  • Snowflake and Guard are great on remotes.

  • RSVP should be used with Caprice Nisei on a remote server for hilarity or put in front of R&D or HQ to further secure Future Perfect.

  • Neural Katana and Komainu should be used wherever you think they can hit

  • Inazuma is probably best used on a server without Caprice Nisei (ie: if Caprice is defending a remote server, install Inazuma in front of Wall of Thorns to protect R&D).

  • Grim should be used to snipe a killer or Deus X

As for operations, feel free to show off with Celebrity Gift if you have multiple assets and an agenda in HQ. It'll make the guessing game fun when you use Mushin No Shin.

Feel free to use a Cerebral Cast without Scorched Earth ready to follow up but it's probably best not to use two of them until you can stick a tag. It's fine if the runner opts for brain damage, it'll make Snares, Project Junebug and Neural Katana all the more fun!

[0] http://www.fantasyflightgames.com/edge_news.asp?eidn=4655

name: Iain's Eleven
description:
The name amused me, and bad pub is also sorta amusing. I don't think it'll play well in any sort of super serious game though.

Criticism welcome.

name: The Stirling Connection (beta)
description:
So basically Iain sits back and enjoys his whiskey with his friends Kati and Mr Li while also keeping on eye on the flow of the game (Taganes, Source, dealer) and building up an early economy (Gorman) that eventually becomes a constant stream of cash (Underworld Contacts, Tri-maf and Favors).

When the time is ripe, he has the finances to keep his (somewhat subpar) breaker suite rollin.

Still under heavy testing. The resource dpt seems pretty solid (maybe trimaf is a bit overkill), perhaps there's room for a Bagbiter experiment. Not too sure about some events and breakers, also I haven't found a better solution than Net Shield against Jinteki.

name: YOU CAN'T CUT BACK ON CARD FUNDING v1.1: OCTGN LEGAL AND REA
description:
YOU WILL REGRET THIS!!!

(just an experiment to see what the maximum number of cards in a deck could be if you include all possible agendas. it's not every card in the game! anyway, time to take this baby to octgn and stomp some nerds

EDITED NOW SO IT'S OCTGN LEGAL. NERD CRUSHING IMMINENT.)

EDIT EDIT: OH NO THE FULL NAME GOT CUT OFF. For posterity, the full name of this deck is: "YOU CAN'T CUT BACK ON CARD FUNDING v1.1: OCTGN LEGAL AND READY TO MEANGLE".

name: Invisible Intrusion type~B
description:
Early on, smack 'em around with facechecks. Keep Grappling Hook or Faerie around in case it's something nasty to facecheck. Build up datasuckers early on weak servers, especially if you can get Security Testing out to also bank up.

Feint + Shutdown once they start rezzing nasty or reasonably expensive ICE to keep you out, as well as allowing an expose. Make sure you constantly hit their hand. When you suspect Agendas after a large draw up period, use a Legwork.

Runs should be nearly free with the Atman module and Desperado, as we all know. The other use of Feint, Grappling Hook and Inside Job is to restart the datasucker engine if they do a purge with ICE still up.

name: Money for Nothing
description: Uses one Core set plus the Genesis cycle. Clickless economy includes the identity ability, recurring creds from Cyberfeeder and Spinal Modem, and Datasucker counters to save on icebreakers. Clicked economy is installing excess things you don't need so you can trash with Aesop's Pawnshop, or using Magnum Opus. Tinkering and Crypsis cover for icebreakers you don't have yet.

name: Recycling Chaos v2
description:
This is meant to be a recycle deck to both cope with damage and get the rig set up as fast as possible.

I've changed the rig from the previous version to use the Atman-Datasucker combination rather than Cloak and Dagger.

My play method is to repeatedly play Diesel/Quality Time and then Freelance Coding Contract for economy to get a rig like this set up:

Atman 0, Atman 2-4 (depending on rez'd ice), Magnum Opus, Djinn w/ 3 Data-suckers.

The Deus X and Sharpshooters are here so you can face-plant on ice early on.

If you end up wallowing in credits thanks to FCC then you can afford to burn the Magnum Opus for the face-plant ice and then install another one later.

This deck relies heavily on Levy AR to keep going, with 3 Diesels (draw 9) and 3 QT's (draw 15) you run through those 40 cards real quick.

name: DELETE ME
NBN Core Tax n' Tag
description: This desk only uses cards available with 1 copy of the core set. Advance agendas through advancement tokens and operations that take advantage of runner tags. Defend servers with taxing ice.

name: Shape The World
description: Shaper monolith :)

name: Foggy Night
description:
A fun idea : a rig in constant evolution, using savoir-faire to install solutions on the go. Don't lose your LARLA, as it's your only recursion. You may even want to mulligan when you have it in your opening hand...

I feel Silhouette is the best fit for this concept, as her abilities gives consistency to the deck as well as key information to decide if a run is worth it or not. Tenma could work too, with an economy more event-oriented and two clone chips instead of LARLA.

name: Gabriel Shoot and Run
description: The use of datasuckers is vital for this deck. Use Hostage for get Masanori and Jones as soon as posible. This deck is fast as hell and has good economy. You can use Test Run and Same Old Thing for recovering lost cards. I will change one tri maf for one desperado but I am only have two cores. Comments are welcome!

name: It's so bad!
description:
Whizzard loves his Power Glove.

I've been tinkering with this for a little while, and this version is better than the previous, but I still feel it lacks a certain something. I've been wavering on Express Delivery vs Quality Time. The nice thing about Delivery is it only costs 1 and I'm frequently very poor.

But man, can Whizzard do an awful damned lot while almost completely broke.

Thus far, my consistently favorite card to draw or search for with Djinn has been Hemorrhage. I make a lot of runs and every two of them means that's at least another ICE I don't have to deal with.

name: Health and Wealth
Cerebral Tennin
description:
Tennin Institute played like Cerebral Imaging! Ice up ONLY your centrals and play the waiting game while you build a hand to set up a score.

You'll want Mushin, Plan B, and a three-point agenda. Mushin out the Plan B, if they run it score a three-pointer, otherwise you have your TOL battery. If you run out of tricks, Reclaimation order them back or Jackson Howard them back too (Remember to install jackson as a single remote and always trigger it when run, which doesn't count as a successful run). If they're not running, then you're advancing ice walls/Plan Bs at the start of your turn.

Your centrals are designed to be as taxing as possible along with cheap ice to rez. You'll want your ice stack to be something like Sensei -> Inazuma -> Eli/Icewall. Hold onto your senseis until you have a least two ice on a server.

name: 1000 Ways to Trap
description:
The idea with this is to punish the runner with wastes of time (clicks) and never being certain if their runs will mean anything. Hopefully the ICE suite is sufficient to hold up R&D and HQ (big reason for Hive being included) for long enough to force the runner into making bad or wasteful choices running the remotes. They'll have to start running remotes or else Sundew's will trickle in insane money, and even a naked Sundew pays for itself and costs the runner 2 clicks and 2 credits. Everything else is just a threat. Having played RP previously, getting naked agenda's out there and scoring them (even 5/3's) is very possible. Shi.Kyu and Shock in archives is a great way to archive-searching.

I'm still a little uncomfortable running only 13 ICE, and would love to hear opinions on how to improve this. Maybe Caprice is worth cutting for 2 more ICE? But which? Just thoughts.

name: NBN is watching you... ʘ_ʘ
description:
My first deck. Trying to make tracing work and tax the runner.

Please comment and give advice, thanks.

name: which trap is which?
A Thousand Pricks
description:
This is basically a copy of the Deck of Knives deck fount at http://netrunnerdb.com/en/decklist/4729/deck-of-knives.

I play tested it a few games and liked it a lot.

I wanted to try a slight variation so I took out the Grids and added another Tor Hanzo (love this card) and wanted to try a Chairman Hiro in the deck to make it more deadly.

The ICE is something I might tweak slightly.

If the Hiro/Hanzo change does not pan our or if I stay happy with the deck I might go back to the original Deck of Knives deck, because it worked so well.

Thanks djackman for the awesome deck idea.

name: Trap or no trap: an annoying Jinteki deck
description: What happens when you have one agenda left to win the game? The runner falls for all of your traps. This deck makes the runner think real hard about install, advance, advance actions. Its supposed to be a fast paced game, before an R&D lock is there, but even then the Snares will help. What is annoying is The Future Perfect. Half your agendas, the runner has to guess the right credits to steal.This has to be the stupidest game mechanism.

name: Core Honey Badger
description: This deck doesn't give a shit.

name: With advance notice v2.3
description:
My new attempt to make something good with Because We Built It.

This deck is about forcing the runner to follow your pace and going into the long run where you are much stronger and dangerous. This is how it achieve it:

  • A LOT of ICE! Most of them pay themselves back for the most part: (Shadow,Tollbooth, Archer) and others are really cheap (Ice Wall, Matrix Analyzer).
  • Only 9 Agenda with 3 that you can score out of your hand to gain 5 credits.
  • Advancing ICE give you more for your buck and make you stronger in mid/long term.
  • Concistency. A lot of the operation you want at low cost, a lot of ICE and only five TRASH cards.
  • Click wise: You won't spend many Click to gain 1 credit or draw one cards. You'll prefer advancing stuff (even if you have to pay for it) and take your time.
  • Comeback Fast: At some point, you'll find a Commercialization and you'll get a ton of credits real quick THEN you can play your Reclamation Order to get even richer.

The runner will spend his effort on your cheap ICE that you keep upgrading each turn while taxing him. There is a SMALL chance that he gonna hit the agenda score before the mid game. By that time there is a good chance that you have already scored a Hostile Takeover and have a remote server with strong ICE (Hadrian's Wall, Archer, Swarm) and ready to settle the game.

Cards:

Corporate Troubleshooter(CT): It can hold a server for a turn when you want to score or when you are want to hurt the runner. Exemple: - Woodcutter + CT: Game ender. There is only one copy as the deck don't focus on flatlining the runner.

  • Archer + CT: Trash 2 of his nastiest programs + ETR.
  • Swarm + CT: Trash EVERYTHING, it's pretty much a reset bottom for the runner.
  • Hadrian's Wall + CT: I don't think you'll need it for this one...

Reclamation Order(RO): You dropped 2-3 BeanStalk or Hedge Fund and need money to rez a Hadrian's Wall next turn? Even better, you played 2-3 Commercialization a few turn before. Hit a RO and laugh with the runner about how ridiculous your credit pool just popped up.

Ice Wall: This is your favorite one early one. You want it on your R&D and keep advancing it up to around 10 if possible. If it gets there then...$$ (chiching). + Ice Wall is better than a Hadrian's Wall at this point simply because a Emergency Shutdown or something similar can't hurt your economy with this one.

name: Jingerly v2
description:
Jingeryly is playing to the theme that the Runner must step lightly, while at the same time, puts the pressure on though the threat of Mushi and Agenda scoring. Make a wrong choice and you're flat-lined.

Not thoroughly tested, and very much looking for feed back on how to make the most deadly and punishing Jinteki deck that pressures Runners into making lethally bad decisions.

Tread gingerly or face quick instant death.

Combos include:

Chum + Komainu

Inazuma + Gyri or Tsurugi or Komaniu

RVSP + Shinobi

A healthy dose of Punitive Counterstrike, Neural EMP and Ronin is included to just deal damage to passive Runners with Hiro to make sure they're within kill range.

Changed the Identity and removed Whirlpool from V1.

name: The Trial of Tennin Institute 1.0
description: My first Corp Deck I have ever put together...sharing a Core Set with my husband right now, not sure I have enough economy to rez any ICE, but I still have to play through this set to see how it pans out. Check back...

name: Tennin Tryout
Mandatory Mushin
description:
Does Mushin make Mandatory Upgrades playable?. This deck aims to see if that's true. Mushin used here as both econ and to make Mandatory scoreable in two turns. I chose this id to slow down YOG ... basically.

This is probably terrible .. but I luv trying to make cards work. Thoughts? Changes?
